content: Corrected a typo and simplified the statement by removing some repetition.

There is an issue with the "Bigger case" validator.
The rule "Two segments may meet at one of their endpoints. They never cross, intersect, or touch midway." is broken with :
- [50 60 60 60] crosses [60 60 55 60]
- [0 40 35 5] crosses [30 30 0 30], [30 0 30 30] and [25 15 20 20]
- [0 40 40 5] crosses [30 30 0 30] and [30 0 30 30]
You should provide an example with a picture. It's still not clear what must be done exactly.

Great contribution. Keep them coming!

If I was someone else, I'd complain I can always go to projecteuler.net when I want a math puzzle. And refuse the puzzle. But I'm not that kind of person.

Random notes:
* it's still pure math now. Could use some wrapping.
* I was amazed (in a positive way) by how little computational geometry I really needed in the end. Like, it fits in a single code line.
* great set of test cases

I'll edit some of the English when I get to it.


Stats (this is pure @Stilgart-teasing): my cleaned up code is 38 lines (<80 chars), including:
* 3 imports lines
* 5 empty lines
* 3 pure comment lines

Ironically, the computational geometry *is* the longest line.
Thanks for the comment (and for the English corrections).

Thanks for the suggestion. Unfortunately, I am not sure it is possible to add a picture (I could not find any documentation).  Do you know a way to do that?

Maybe  I could add a link.

Hi

[50 60 60 60] cannot cross [60 60 55 60] as they have a common endpoint (60, 60). 

However, you are right for the two other cases, I probably inverted the x and the y axis of the second endpoint of the segments.

I would say that [50 60 60 60] and [60 60 55 60] cross infinitly since one contains the other.
Anyway, thanks for the fix.

Ho, right! 
i inverted those coordinates too :)

I just need some time to check if I inverted the coordinates of (50, 60) or of (55, 60).
Yep. Furthermore the issue is with [50 60 60 60], [60 60 55 60] and [55 60 50 60] because one contains the other two.

I do not know where my brain messed up (neither (55 60 nor 50 60 could be inverted without violating the conditions). I changed the point (55 60) by (55 63).

I also checked the instances with a script with turtle, it should be okay now.

Thanks for checking.

The main issue I am facing is the "cyclic continuous curve", browsing google does not help me that much.
Therefore I believe you can :
- draw in ASCII
- or upload an image on an external website and post the link
- or post a link to an external website about the "cyclic continuous curve" that is clear enough for us
Thanks
As drawing this in ascii would be extremely difficult for me, I uploaded two examples on imgur and edited the subject.
